content:
I just watched an old youtube video where Scott Morrison makes a demo of lean. At some point, he shows tactic called back?, that looks quite powerful, and mentions it was experimental. I have looked for it in current lean but didn't find it.

Waas it actually added to lean/mathlib, or it never went beyond and experiment?
pretty sure the answer is no, although it is similar to apply_rules. Perhaps @Scott Morrison can say more

Scott Morrison said:

aesop does everything back aspired to!

Is it in lean3/mathlib3? or only for Lean4?
I vaguelly remember there was a Lean 3 attempt, but in practice the only usable version is in Lean 4.

[Quotingâ€¦]
In my case, there are mainly two obstacles to migrate to Lean4:

  • mathlib4 still lacks some things (this is improving, so for many cases is not a big issue)
  • the convenience of having a working lean-mathlib enviromente just by downloading and uncompressing the tryleanfile is not available for Lean4, as far as i am aware.

Is there a similarly easy way to get a Lean4-mathlib4 enviroment?

Scott Morrison said:

Lean 3 is dead, long live Lean 4. :-)

Lean 3: "Tis only a flesh wound"
Lean 4: "Only a flesh wound? Your arm is off!"
@Miguel Marco, I think the current easiest options are to use codespaces or gitpod. My understanding is that simply opening the mathlib4 repo in either is all you need to do.
I agree though that we should have a downloadable bundle.
One obstacle is that olean files are unfortunately much larger in Lean 4.

Scott Morrison said:

One obstacle is that olean files are unfortunately much larger in Lean 4.

How much are we talking about? Unless we are talking about something unreasonable, I think it would be worth having it.
Very rough estimate: my mathlib4 directory is 4 times larger than my mathlib directory. (git histories live elsewhere, so I'm not including that)

Scott Morrison said:

Very rough estimate: my mathlib4 directory is 4 times larger than my mathlib directory. (git histories live elsewhere, so I'm not including that)

Currently, the trylean bundle is less than 500MB. That would mean going to about 2GB. It is big, but nothing extraordinary nowadays.
